messages.message: For those who are interested in low level CPU performance [where the landscape of CPU processing speed is heading to] -- this is a really cool article. Given that we have almost maxed out on how much you can increase the clock frequency (end of Moore's law) without killing the battery, I wouldn't be surprised if the future moves towards SoC (System on Chip).
That was a good read indeed. Sign me up for an M1.

We should test if everything we need from development at Instabase perspective can run on M1. Docker support for M1 is still in beta but once that is officially supported, we should move to M1 as default laptop for all Instabase employees [including our engineers]. + @zach

Happy to volunteer to test :slightly_smiling_face:

Agreed that the design is amazing and it’s super cool that such a complex system (most of the different compute workloads people run) can be optimized for in such an elegant way.

I’m curious if developing software _for_ M1 is any different if you want to use some of those application-specific chips (like maybe now you “have” to use CoreML to run ml workloads) or if it semi-magically figures it out (like Intel’s old branch prediction secret sauce)
I think it might be the former — pretty sure that’s how iOS has worked since they launched neural engine
